articles.headline: Miss Your Flight?
articles.snippet: For top executives and other business travelers, this is the year of the downgrade. Trips have become shorter, less frequent and less luxurious.
articles.abstract: For top executives and other business travelers, this is the year of the downgrade. Trips have become shorter, less frequent and less luxurious.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Fritz Henderson found out in March that he was replacing Rick Wagoner as chief executive of General Motors, he did something it’s very likely no recent G.M. chief executive ever did on the day he was promoted. He flew home commercial.

articles.headline: Wi-Fi to Go, No Cafe Needed
articles.snippet: Novatel’s MiFi 2200 provides the unthinkable: a universal wireless bubble you can take anywhere.
articles.abstract: Novatel’s MiFi 2200 provides the unthinkable: a universal wireless bubble you can take anywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Someday, we’ll tell our grandchildren how we had to drive around town looking for a coffee shop when we needed to get online, and they’ll laugh their heads off. Every building in America has running water, electricity and ventilation; what’s the holdup on universal wireless Internet?

articles.headline: New Effort Reopens a Medical Minefield
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s initiative to compare the effectiveness of medical treatments is drawing criticism from medical products companies, some doctors and others.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s initiative to compare the effectiveness of medical treatments is drawing criticism from medical products companies, some doctors and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: A back-pain researcher, Dr. Richard Deyo recalls the uproar the last time federal officials tried to suggest how doctors should practice their profession.

articles.headline: Pakistan Strife Fills a Hospital With Refugees
articles.snippet: Battles unfolding across a 50-mile arc northwest of Pakistan’s capital are driving civilians from their homes.
articles.abstract: Battles unfolding across a 50-mile arc northwest of Pakistan’s capital are driving civilians from their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARDAN, Pakistan — The dank and shadowed hallways of the Mardan Tuberculosis Hospital, crumbling relic of another age, were transformed here on Wednesday into a clinic of a more modern sort, when the refugees of nearby battles came streaming in the whole long day.

articles.headline: G.M. Is Said to Seek Stake in Fiat
articles.snippet: Discussions between Fiat and General Motors are broadening to include not only a sale of G.M.’s Opel unit, but other G.M. operations as well, in exchange for a stake in the Italian automaker.
articles.abstract: Discussions between Fiat and General Motors are broadening to include not only a sale of G.M.’s Opel unit, but other G.M. operations as well, in exchange for a stake in the Italian automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years after paying $2 billion to extricate itself from a partnership with Fiat, General Motors is seeking a stake in the Italian automaker in exchange for its Latin American and European operations.

articles.headline: Banks Need Funds, but Taxpayers May Not Have to Pay
articles.snippet: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
articles.abstract: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The results of the bank stress tests have been trickling out for days, from Washington and from Wall Street, and the leaks seem to confirm what many bankers feel in their bones: despite all those bailouts, some of the nation’s largest banks still need more money.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: For Small Employers, Shedding Workers and Tears
articles.snippet: The often personal task of laying off workers can inflict a large emotional toll on small-business managers.
articles.abstract: The often personal task of laying off workers can inflict a large emotional toll on small-business managers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAFTON, Wis.  In a small, windowless conference room, the nine members of the management team at Ram Tool gathered to consider which employees should be laid off in the company’s latest round of cutbacks. They debated each name and weighed issues like seniority and skills. Could they do multiple jobs? What was their attendance record?

articles.headline: Deal Reached to Keep Boston Globe in Print
articles.snippet: If approved by workers, a package of wage, benefit and job security concessions will head off the threatened closing of the largest newspaper in Boston.
articles.abstract: If approved by workers, a package of wage, benefit and job security concessions will head off the threatened closing of the largest newspaper in Boston.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stare-down between The New York Times Company and workers at The Boston Globe reached its crucial moment Wednesday when the newspaper’s largest union agreed to vote on a package of painful wage, benefit and job security concessions that would head off the threatened closure of one of America’s premier newspapers, but could also presage significant layoffs.

articles.headline: More States Start Pension Inquiries
articles.snippet: Andrew M. Cuomo’s investigation into New York’s comptroller’s office has expanded into a broad look at more than 100 firms by attorneys general in dozens of other states.
articles.abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo’s investigation into New York’s comptroller’s office has expanded into a broad look at more than 100 firms by attorneys general in dozens of other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sprawling investigation into New York’s pension investments hints at a much bigger problem than the handful of indictments so far would suggest.

articles.headline: As Gay Issues Arise, Obama Is Pressed to Engage
articles.snippet: Some gay activists have counseled patience, but others are suspicious of his commitment to their cause.
articles.abstract: Some gay activists have counseled patience, but others are suspicious of his commitment to their cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama was noticeably silent last month when the Iowa Supreme Court overturned the state’s ban on same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: G.M., Leaking Cash, Faces Bigger Chance of Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Analysts say the company looks less viable than it did five months ago, when the government stepped in with its bailout.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the company looks less viable than it did five months ago, when the government stepped in with its bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Even after receiving $15.4 billion in federal loans, General Motors is once again on the brink of financial collapse.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
